Expectation1: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation1: A procedural hearing on a minor matter can easily be postponed if necessary.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story: I glanced at my calendar and felt the familiar knot tighten in my stomach. The court had scheduled a procedural hearing for one of my clients—a minor matter, nothing urgent, and I knew I could request a postponement without much trouble. Still, as their lawyer, I was expected to be present, to show commitment and diligence, even for the small things. At the same time, tonight was the adult education class at the synagogue. It was an optional, drop-in session, but I knew several people were looking forward to it. As their rabbi, I was expected to be there, to teach, to answer questions, to guide. I could almost hear the disappointment in their voices if I canceled last minute. The two roles pulled at me from opposite sides—my client’s trust in my professional reliability, my congregation’s trust in my spiritual leadership. I sat at my desk, torn, the weight of both expectations pressing down, unsure which responsibility I would have to let down.
